questions.stem: A 14-year-old girl who reached menarche at age 9 presents with depressive symptoms, poor body image, and reports that most of her friends are 16- to 18-year-old males. Which of the following best explains the developmental risk pattern described in this vignette?

options.text: Late-maturing girls experience a mismatch between cognitive maturity and social expectations
Early-maturing girls face elevated psychosocial risk due to a mismatch between physical maturity and psychosocial readiness
Adolescent egocentrism causes early-maturing girls to overestimate the attention they receive from others
The personal fable leads early-maturing girls to believe they are uniquely immune to social pressures

questions.explanation: Research consistently shows that early-maturing girls are at elevated risk for depression, anxiety, eating disorders, substance use, early sexual activity, and association with older peers. This occurs because physical maturation outpaces psychosocial and cognitive development, creating a mismatch. Late-maturing girls generally fare well. While adolescent egocentrism and the personal fable are relevant adolescent phenomena, they do not specifically explain the risk profile of early pubertal timing.

questions.stem: A researcher presents adolescents with the following problem: 'If all flurps are green, and all green things glow in the dark, do flurps glow in the dark?' A 13-year-old correctly answers 'yes' despite never encountering a flurp. This ability is best characterized as:

options.text: Concrete operational classification skills applied to a novel category
Propositional thought—the ability to evaluate the logic of verbal statements independent of real-world referents
Hypothetical-deductive reasoning as demonstrated in the pendulum problem
Postformal thinking that integrates subjective and objective logic

questions.explanation: Propositional thought, a hallmark of Piaget's formal operational stage, is the ability to evaluate the logical structure of verbal statements without requiring real-world referents. The adolescent treats the premises as given and draws a valid conclusion purely from the logical structure. Hypothetical-deductive reasoning involves systematically testing hypotheses (as in the pendulum problem). Concrete operational children would struggle with premises that contradict or have no connection to reality. Postformal thinking is a concept applied to adult cognition, not early adolescence.

questions.stem: According to Steinberg's dual systems model, adolescent risk-taking in the presence of peers is best explained by:

options.text: Adolescents' inability to perceive risk accurately, combined with underdeveloped reasoning abilities
A hyper-responsive socioemotional reward system overwhelming an immature cognitive control system, with peers amplifying reward sensitivity
Peer pressure causing adolescents to abandon their own values and adopt group norms through informational influence
Incomplete myelination of the limbic system causing emotional dysregulation that peers exacerbate through modeling

questions.explanation: Steinberg's dual systems model posits that adolescent risk-taking results from a mismatch between the early-maturing socioemotional system (limbic system, especially the nucleus accumbens) and the late-maturing cognitive control system (prefrontal cortex). Critically, the model emphasizes that adolescents generally CAN perceive risk accurately—the problem is that the reward system overwhelms the regulatory system, especially in the presence of peers who amplify reward sensitivity. The limbic system matures early (not incompletely), and the issue is not informational influence or value abandonment.

questions.stem: Research on Piaget's formal operational stage indicates that when college students are tested across multiple task domains:

options.text: Virtually all demonstrate consistent formal operational reasoning across all domains by age 18
Only about 40–60% demonstrate formal operational reasoning, and its application tends to be domain-specific
Formal operations are universally achieved by age 15 but may appear absent due to test anxiety
Cross-cultural studies show no variability in the rate of formal operational attainment

questions.explanation: Piaget himself acknowledged that not all adolescents or adults achieve full formal operational thought. Subsequent research has confirmed that only about 40–60% of college students in Western samples demonstrate formal operations when tested across multiple task domains. Furthermore, formal operational reasoning tends to be domain-specific—an individual may show formal reasoning in their area of expertise but not in unfamiliar domains. The achievement of formal operations varies considerably across cultures and educational contexts.

questions.stem: According to Erikson, the virtue that emerges from successful resolution of the Identity vs. Role Confusion stage is:

options.text: Competence
Love
Fidelity
Will

questions.explanation: Erikson identified fidelity—loyalty to values, people, and ideologies—as the virtue that emerges from successful resolution of the Identity vs. Role Confusion crisis during adolescence. Competence is the virtue from Industry vs. Inferiority (school age), Love is the virtue from Intimacy vs. Isolation (young adulthood), and Will is the virtue from Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt (toddlerhood).

questions.stem: Select all findings that are consistent with research on early pubertal timing in adolescents.

options.text: Early-maturing girls are at elevated risk for depression, eating disorders, and substance use
Early-maturing boys may experience initial social advantages but also increased risk for externalizing behaviors
Late-maturing boys consistently show the poorest long-term outcomes of any pubertal timing group
The secular trend shows that average age of menarche has decreased by approximately 3–4 years over the past 150 years in Western nations
Early maturation in both sexes is associated with decreased peer influence due to faster prefrontal cortex development

questions.explanation: Research consistently shows that early-maturing girls face the greatest psychosocial risks (depression, eating disorders, substance use, association with older peers). Early-maturing boys experience mixed outcomes—initial social advantages (popularity, athletics) but also increased risk for externalizing problems and substance use. The secular trend has shifted menarche approximately 3–4 years earlier over 150 years. Late-maturing boys experience temporary social disadvantage, but effects typically diminish by adulthood—they do not show the poorest long-term outcomes. Early maturation does not accelerate PFC development.

questions.stem: Select all statements that accurately describe Marcia's identity status model.

options.text: Identity statuses are defined by two dimensions: exploration (crisis) and commitment
Identity achievement involves having explored alternatives and made firm commitments
Identity statuses represent a fixed, invariant sequence that all adolescents traverse in order
Identity foreclosure involves commitment to an identity adopted from authority figures without personal exploration
Identity moratorium is the status most associated with psychological distress and depression

questions.explanation: Marcia's model defines four identity statuses along two dimensions: exploration (crisis) and commitment. Identity achievement involves high past exploration and high commitment. Foreclosure involves high commitment without exploration, typically adopting values from authority figures. Critically, identity statuses are NOT fixed stages—individuals can move between statuses over time, though the general trajectory is toward achievement. Identity diffusion (not moratorium) is the status most associated with psychological distress, depression, and substance use. Moratorium involves active exploration and may involve some anxiety, but it is a normative and often productive developmental state.

questions.stem: Select all characteristics that are hallmarks of Piaget's formal operational stage of cognitive development.

options.text: Hypothetical-deductive reasoning—the ability to generate and systematically test hypotheses
Conservation—understanding that quantity remains the same despite changes in appearance
Abstract thought—reasoning about concepts like justice and freedom not tied to concrete reality
Propositional thought—evaluating the logic of verbal statements without real-world referents
Transitive inference—mentally ordering objects along a quantitative dimension

questions.explanation: The three key achievements of formal operational thought are: (1) hypothetical-deductive reasoning (generating hypotheses and systematically testing them, as in the pendulum problem), (2) abstract thought (reasoning about ideas, concepts, and possibilities not tied to concrete reality), and (3) propositional thought (evaluating the logical structure of verbal statements independent of real-world circumstances). Conservation is a hallmark of the concrete operational stage, and transitive inference also emerges during concrete operations.

questions.stem: Select all findings that are supported by neuroscience research on the adolescent brain.

options.text: The prefrontal cortex continues myelination and synaptic pruning into the mid-20s
The socioemotional system, centered on the limbic system, matures rapidly during puberty
Adolescents show adult-like decision-making under conditions of emotional arousal and peer presence
Adolescent brain research has been cited in U.S. Supreme Court decisions regarding juvenile sentencing
The amygdala completes maturation simultaneously with the prefrontal cortex in late adolescence

questions.explanation: Neuroscience research confirms that: (1) the PFC undergoes prolonged development with myelination and synaptic pruning continuing into the mid-20s; (2) the socioemotional/limbic system matures rapidly during puberty, creating a mismatch with the slower-developing PFC; (3) this research has been cited in landmark Supreme Court cases (Roper v. Simmons, Graham v. Florida, Miller v. Alabama). Adolescents can reason well in calm settings but actually show WORSE decision-making under emotional arousal and peer presence—the opposite of option (c). The amygdala (part of the limbic system) matures earlier than the PFC, not simultaneously.

questions.stem: Select all accurate statements about peer influence during adolescence.

options.text: Susceptibility to peer pressure peaks around ages 14–15 and then gradually declines
Peer presence increases risk-taking in adolescents but not in adults, as shown in driving simulation research
Peers can only exert negative influence on adolescent behavior and development
Resistance to peer influence increases linearly from ages 14 to 18 and then stabilizes
Peer influence on risk-taking operates solely through conscious social pressure rather than reward sensitivity

questions.explanation: Research by Steinberg and Monahan (2007) shows that susceptibility to peer pressure peaks around ages 14–15, with resistance increasing linearly from 14 to 18 and stabilizing in early adulthood. Driving simulation studies demonstrate that peer presence increases risk-taking in adolescents but not adults. Importantly, peers can exert BOTH positive and negative influence—supporting academic achievement, prosocial behavior, and healthy identity exploration. The mechanism is not solely conscious pressure; the dual systems model indicates that peers amplify reward sensitivity in the socioemotional system, which is a neurobiological rather than purely social process.

questions.stem: Match each of Marcia's identity statuses with its correct characterization based on exploration and commitment levels.
questions.explanation: Marcia's four identity statuses are defined by levels of exploration (crisis) and commitment: Identity Diffusion = low exploration and low commitment (no active searching, no commitments made). Identity Foreclosure = low exploration but high commitment (adopting identity from authority figures without questioning). Identity Moratorium = high exploration but low commitment (actively searching but not yet decided). Identity Achievement = high past exploration and high current commitment (has explored and made firm choices).

questions.stem: Match each adolescent cognitive phenomenon with its correct description.

columns.text: Belief that others are constantly observing and evaluating one's appearance and behavior
Belief that one's experiences are unique and that one is special or invulnerable
Systematically generating and testing hypotheses while varying one variable at a time
Evaluating the logic of verbal statements without requiring real-world referents

questions.explanation: The imaginary audience is Elkind's concept describing adolescents' belief that others are as preoccupied with their appearance and behavior as they are themselves, leading to heightened self-consciousness. The personal fable is the complementary belief that one's experiences are uniquely special and that one is invulnerable. Hypothetical-deductive reasoning (demonstrated by Piaget's pendulum problem) involves systematic hypothesis testing. Propositional thought involves evaluating logical statements independent of real-world truth.

questions.stem: For each pubertal timing pattern, select ALL associated outcomes supported by research.

columns.text: Elevated risk for depression and eating disorders
Temporary lower self-esteem and social disadvantage
Generally favorable adjustment and possible body image advantages

questions.explanation: Early-maturing girls face the most problematic outcomes, including elevated risk for depression, anxiety, eating disorders, substance use, and association with older peers. Early-maturing boys experience initial social advantages due to greater physical size and athletic ability, though they also show increased risk for externalizing problems. Late-maturing boys may experience social disadvantage and lower self-esteem during adolescence, though effects typically diminish by adulthood. Late-maturing girls generally fare well and may even experience advantages in body image and adjustment.

questions.stem: For each brain region or system, select ALL accurate descriptions of its role in the dual systems model of adolescent risk-taking.

columns.text: Supports executive functions, impulse control, and planning

questions.explanation: In Steinberg's dual systems model: The prefrontal cortex (PFC) is responsible for executive functions, impulse control, planning, and decision-making, and it continues myelination and synaptic pruning into the mid-20s. The limbic system, particularly the nucleus accumbens, processes reward and emotional arousal and matures rapidly during puberty. The amygdala, also part of the limbic system, processes emotional arousal and fear responses and matures early. Overall brain development, particularly PFC maturation, continues into the mid-20s, creating the developmental mismatch central to the model.

questions.stem: According to Elkind (1967), adolescent egocentrism manifests in two cognitive distortions. The {{blank1}} is the belief that others are constantly watching and evaluating one's behavior, leading to heightened {{blank2}}. The {{blank3}} is the belief that one's experiences are uniquely special and that one is invulnerable, which contributes to adolescent {{blank4}}.

options.text: imaginary audience
personal fable
spotlight effect
looking-glass self
self-consciousness
identity diffusion
formal operational thought
moral reasoning
imaginary audience
personal fable
invincibility fable
self-serving bias
identity achievement
peer conformity
risk-taking behavior
conservation failure

questions.explanation: Elkind proposed that the emergence of abstract thinking in adolescence gives rise to two forms of egocentrism: (1) the imaginary audience—the belief that others are as preoccupied with one's appearance and behavior as oneself, leading to heightened self-consciousness; and (2) the personal fable—the belief that one's experiences are unique and that one is invulnerable, which contributes to risk-taking behavior ('It won't happen to me'). These concepts are distinct from the spotlight effect (a social psychology concept), the looking-glass self (Cooley's symbolic interactionism), and the invincibility fable (a related but distinct term not used by Elkind).

questions.stem: In Marcia's identity status model, an adolescent who has adopted career goals based entirely on parental expectations without personal exploration is in {{blank1}}. A classmate who is actively exploring multiple career paths but has not yet committed is in {{blank2}}. The status most associated with psychological well-being is {{blank3}}, while the status most associated with psychological distress is {{blank4}}.

identity diffusion
identity moratorium

questions.explanation: In Marcia's model: Identity foreclosure involves commitment without exploration—adopting an identity from authority figures without questioning (e.g., following parental career expectations). Identity moratorium involves active exploration without yet committing. Identity achievement is associated with the highest psychological well-being—higher self-esteem, better stress management, and more mature relationships. Identity diffusion is most associated with psychological distress, including depression, substance use, and interpersonal difficulties.

questions.stem: A 16-year-old is brought to therapy after being caught driving recklessly with friends in the car. He states, 'I knew it was dangerous, but it didn't feel dangerous at the time—my friends were egging me on and it felt amazing.'

options.text: Early maturation of the socioemotional reward system relative to the cognitive control system
Peer presence amplifying reward sensitivity in the nucleus accumbens
Inability to cognitively perceive or understand the risk of reckless driving
Complete absence of prefrontal cortex functioning during adolescence
Steinberg's dual systems model of adolescent risk-taking
Piaget's formal operational stage of cognitive development
Erikson's identity vs. role confusion crisis
Impulsive or risky behavior may reflect neurodevelopmental immaturity rather than fixed character traits
Therapeutic interventions should address context-dependent decision-making rather than assuming cognitive deficits
The adolescent should be diagnosed with conduct disorder given the reckless behavior
Risk-taking will persist unchanged into adulthood as PFC maturation is complete by age 16

questions.explanation: This vignette illustrates Steinberg's dual systems model. The contributing factors are: (1) the mismatch between the early-maturing socioemotional system and the late-maturing cognitive control system, and (2) peer presence amplifying reward sensitivity. The adolescent explicitly states he KNEW it was dangerous (ruling out inability to perceive risk) but it 'didn't feel dangerous'—consistent with the model's emphasis on reward sensitivity overwhelming cognitive control. The PFC is not completely absent but immature. Implications include recognizing that risky behavior reflects neurodevelopmental immaturity (not necessarily a conduct disorder) and that interventions should target context-dependent decision-making. PFC maturation continues into the mid-20s, not 16.

questions.stem: A college freshman tells her counselor: 'I declared pre-law because that's what my dad does and he's always expected me to follow him. I never really thought about whether I want to do anything else. But lately I've been feeling suffocated and I don't know who I really am.'

options.text: Commitment to an identity adopted from an authority figure without personal exploration
Emerging awareness that adopted commitments may not reflect authentic personal values
Successful completion of the identity exploration process resulting in stable commitments
Apathetic disengagement from all identity-related goals and values
Transition from identity foreclosure toward identity moratorium
Identity achievement with subsequent regression to diffusion
Normative identity diffusion characteristic of emerging adulthood
Therapy should support the exploration process and help the client engage with moratorium
The counselor should validate that questioning foreclosed commitments can be a healthy developmental step
The counselor should reinforce the father's expectations to reduce the client's distress
The client should be diagnosed with an adjustment disorder since identity questioning is pathological

questions.explanation: This client initially adopted her career identity from her father without exploration (identity foreclosure: low exploration, high commitment). Her growing discomfort suggests she is beginning to question these foreclosed commitments and may be transitioning toward moratorium (high exploration, low commitment). This is not identity achievement (which requires completed exploration) or diffusion (which involves apathy rather than active distress about identity). Therapeutically, the counselor should support the exploration process and validate that questioning foreclosed identities is a healthy developmental step, not pathology. Reinforcing the father's expectations would maintain foreclosure.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe aspects of adolescent brain development and its implications.
questions.passage: Research on the adolescent brain has revealed several important findings. [The prefrontal cortex, responsible for executive functions and impulse control, is among the last brain regions to fully mature, with development continuing into the mid-20s]. [The limbic system and prefrontal cortex mature at the same rate, reaching full development simultaneously during puberty]. [Steinberg's dual systems model posits that adolescent risk-taking results from a hyper-responsive reward system overwhelming an immature cognitive control system]. [Adolescents take risks primarily because they cannot cognitively understand that dangerous activities are dangerous]. [Neuroscience evidence on adolescent brain development has been cited in U.S. Supreme Court decisions, including Roper v. Simmons, Graham v. Florida, and Miller v. Alabama]. [The presence of peers has no effect on adolescent risk-taking behavior in experimental studies using driving simulation tasks].

highlightableSegments.text: The prefrontal cortex, responsible for executive functions and impulse control, is among the last brain regions to fully mature, with development continuing into the mid-20s
The limbic system and prefrontal cortex mature at the same rate, reaching full development simultaneously during puberty
Steinberg's dual systems model posits that adolescent risk-taking results from a hyper-responsive reward system overwhelming an immature cognitive control system
Adolescents take risks primarily because they cannot cognitively understand that dangerous activities are dangerous
Neuroscience evidence on adolescent brain development has been cited in U.S. Supreme Court decisions, including Roper v. Simmons, Graham v. Florida, and Miller v. Alabama
The presence of peers has no effect on adolescent risk-taking behavior in experimental studies using driving simulation tasks

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 5 are accurate. The PFC is among the last regions to mature (continuing into the mid-20s). The dual systems model correctly describes the mismatch between reward and control systems. Neuroscience has influenced Supreme Court juvenile sentencing decisions. Statement 2 is false—the limbic system matures EARLIER than the PFC, creating the critical mismatch. Statement 4 is false—adolescents generally CAN perceive risk; the issue is that reward sensitivity overwhelms cognitive control. Statement 6 is false—peer presence INCREASES adolescent risk-taking in driving simulations.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe Marcia's identity status theory and Erikson's adolescent stage.
questions.passage: Identity development is central to adolescent psychology. [Erikson identified Identity vs. Role Confusion as the central psychosocial crisis of adolescence, with fidelity as the virtue that emerges from successful resolution]. [Marcia operationalized Erikson's theory by proposing four identity statuses based on two dimensions: exploration and commitment]. [Identity statuses are fixed, invariant stages that all adolescents traverse in the same sequence from diffusion to achievement]. [Identity moratorium, characterized by active exploration without commitment, may involve some anxiety but is a normative and often productive developmental state]. [Identity diffusion is the status most associated with psychological distress, including depression and substance use]. [Identity foreclosure, characterized by high exploration and low commitment, represents the most adaptive identity status].

highlightableSegments.text: Erikson identified Identity vs. Role Confusion as the central psychosocial crisis of adolescence, with fidelity as the virtue that emerges from successful resolution
Marcia operationalized Erikson's theory by proposing four identity statuses based on two dimensions: exploration and commitment
Identity statuses are fixed, invariant stages that all adolescents traverse in the same sequence from diffusion to achievement
Identity moratorium, characterized by active exploration without commitment, may involve some anxiety but is a normative and often productive developmental state
Identity diffusion is the status most associated with psychological distress, including depression and substance use
Identity foreclosure, characterized by high exploration and low commitment, represents the most adaptive identity status

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, 4, and 5 are accurate. Erikson did identify Identity vs. Role Confusion as the central adolescent crisis with fidelity as its virtue. Marcia did operationalize Erikson's theory using exploration and commitment dimensions. Moratorium is a normative state of active exploration. Diffusion is indeed most associated with distress. Statement 3 is false—statuses are NOT fixed stages; individuals can move between them. Statement 6 is false—foreclosure is characterized by LOW exploration and HIGH commitment (not the reverse), and identity ACHIEVEMENT (not foreclosure) is the most adaptive status.

questions.stem: Arrange the typical sequence of pubertal changes in GIRLS from earliest to latest.

items.text: Breast development (thelarche)
Pubic hair growth
Growth spurt
Menarche (first menstruation)
Completion of breast development
Adult body composition established

questions.explanation: In girls, puberty follows a predictable sequence: (1) Breast development (thelarche) is typically the first visible sign; (2) Pubic hair growth follows shortly after; (3) The growth spurt accelerates; (4) Menarche (first menstruation) typically occurs around age 12–13, after the peak of the growth spurt; (5) Breast development reaches adult form; and (6) Adult body composition is established as puberty concludes. While individual timing varies widely, this sequence is remarkably consistent.

questions.stem: Arrange Marcia's identity statuses in the typical (though not invariant) developmental trajectory from least to most mature.

items.text: Identity Diffusion (no exploration, no commitment)
Identity Foreclosure (commitment without exploration)
Beginning of active identity questioning
Identity Moratorium (active exploration, no commitment yet)
Integration of explored alternatives with personal values
Identity Achievement (exploration completed, firm commitments made)

questions.explanation: While Marcia emphasized that identity statuses are not fixed stages and individuals can move between them, the general developmental trajectory moves from diffusion (no engagement) through foreclosure (premature commitment from authority figures) toward moratorium (active exploration) and eventually achievement (completed exploration with firm commitments). The process involves initial questioning, active exploration during moratorium, integration of explored alternatives, and ultimately the formation of committed identity. This trajectory is typical but NOT invariant—some individuals may skip statuses or regress.

questions.stem: A longitudinal study tracks susceptibility to peer influence and prefrontal cortex (PFC) maturation from early adolescence through early adulthood.
questions.question: Which conclusion is best supported by the data pattern shown?

options.text: Susceptibility to peer influence increases steadily throughout adolescence and into adulthood
Susceptibility to peer influence peaks around ages 14–15 and then declines as PFC maturation progresses, stabilizing in early adulthood
PFC maturation is complete by age 18, after which peer influence has no effect
There is no relationship between PFC development and susceptibility to peer influence

questions.explanation: The data pattern shows that susceptibility to peer influence peaks around age 14 and then declines as PFC maturation progresses—consistent with Steinberg and Monahan's (2007) finding that resistance to peer influence increases linearly from ages 14 to 18 and then stabilizes. PFC maturation continues well into the mid-20s (not complete at 18). The inverse relationship between the two measures supports the dual systems model, which posits that the immature PFC cannot adequately regulate the hyper-responsive reward system, particularly in peer contexts.

questions.stem: A researcher tracks the prevalence of different identity statuses among a cohort of students from early adolescence through college.
questions.question: What developmental trend in identity status is best supported by this data?

options.text: The majority of adolescents remain in identity diffusion throughout adolescence and into adulthood
There is a normative developmental shift from diffusion and foreclosure toward moratorium and achievement across adolescence and emerging adulthood
Identity achievement is reached by all individuals before age 17
Identity foreclosure becomes increasingly common as adolescents age into adulthood

questions.explanation: The data shows a clear developmental shift: the combined prevalence of diffusion and foreclosure (the less mature statuses) declines from 70% at age 13 to 15% at age 22, while moratorium and achievement (the more mature statuses involving exploration) increase correspondingly. This pattern is consistent with research showing that the general developmental trajectory moves from diffusion and foreclosure toward moratorium and eventually achievement—though this process extends well into emerging adulthood for many individuals and is neither universal nor invariant.

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical presentation as reflecting the imaginary audience, the personal fable, or identity diffusion.

items.text: A 15-year-old refuses to go to school because she has a small pimple and insists 'everyone will stare at me'
A 16-year-old drives recklessly, stating 'Accidents happen to other people, not me'
A 17-year-old presents as apathetic about career planning, relationships, and values, stating 'I don't really care about any of that'
A 14-year-old spends 2 hours getting ready for school, convinced that classmates will notice every detail of his outfit
A 15-year-old tells her therapist 'You couldn't possibly understand what I'm going through—no one has ever felt this way'
A 19-year-old has no commitments, no direction, and shows signs of depression and substance use with no engagement in exploration

questions.explanation: Imaginary audience presentations involve the belief that others are constantly watching and evaluating—leading to heightened self-consciousness (refusing to go to school over a pimple, spending excessive time on appearance). Personal fable presentations involve a sense of uniqueness and invulnerability—driving recklessly because 'it won't happen to me' or believing no one could understand one's unique experiences. Identity diffusion involves no exploration and no commitment, often appearing as apathy, disengagement, or directionlessness, and is associated with depression and substance use.

questions.stem: Categorize each description as belonging to the socioemotional system, the cognitive control system, or Piaget's formal operational stage.

items.text: Processes reward and emotional arousal; centered on the nucleus accumbens and amygdala
Supports impulse control, planning, and consideration of consequences
Enables hypothetical-deductive reasoning and systematic hypothesis testing
Matures rapidly during puberty, creating heightened sensitivity to peer influence
Continues myelination and synaptic pruning into the mid-20s
Demonstrated by Piaget using the pendulum problem to assess systematic variable isolation

questions.explanation: The socioemotional system (limbic) processes reward and emotional arousal, is centered on the nucleus accumbens and amygdala, and matures rapidly during puberty—creating heightened sensitivity to peer influence and reward. The cognitive control system (PFC) supports executive functions like impulse control, planning, and considering consequences, and continues to mature into the mid-20s. Piaget's formal operational stage, assessed by tasks like the pendulum problem, involves hypothetical-deductive reasoning and the ability to systematically isolate variables. The dual systems model describes the first two; Piaget's theory describes the cognitive capacity that emerges during adolescence.
